anchor.surface_text: Now the contention of the appellant is that assuming that he had failed to establish the case put forward by him, it does not follow as a matter of law that the amounts in question were income received or accrued during the previous year, that it was the duty of the Department to adduce evidence to show from what source the income was derived and why it should be treated as concealed income. In the absence of such evidence, it is argued, the finding is erroneous. We are unable to agree. issues.text: Whether, upon the assessee failing to establish his explanations for the source of the cash credits, the amounts in question must be treated as income received or accrued during the previous year relevant to the assessment years, or whether the Department is required to adduce evidence showing the source and why it should be treated as concealed income

anchor.surface_text: Now the contention of the appellant is that assuming that he had failed to establish the case put forward by him, it does not follow as a matter of law that the amounts in question were income received or accrued during the previous year, that it was the duty of the Department to adduce evidence to show from what source the income was derived and why it should be treated as concealed income. In the absence of such evidence, it is argued, the finding is erroneous. We are unable to agree.

issues.text: Whether an appeal under Article 136 of the Constitution lies directly against the decision of the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal when an application for reference to the High Court under section 66(2) of the Indian Income-tax Act has been dismissed and no appeal has been preferred against that order

arguments.claim: Appeal under Art 136 against Tribunal not open on grounds taken or available in dismissed s66(2) High Court reference where no appeal preferred against HC order; would question Tribunal via final HC decision

holdings.text: Where an assessee fails to prove satisfactorily the source and nature of certain amount of cash received during the accounting year, the Income-tax Officer is entitled to draw the inference that the receipts are of an assessable nature.

anchor.surface_text: There is ample authority for the position that where an assessee fails to prove satisfactorily the source and nature of certain amount of cash received during the accounting year, the Income-tax Officer is entitled to draw the inference that the receipts are of an assessable nature.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejection of assessee's explanations for cash credits in firm account books leaves no alternative but to treat as concealed income; principle depends on facts and circumstances with ample precedent support.

holdings.text: When both these explanations were rejected, as they have been it was clearly open to the Income-tax Officer to hold that the [amounts] must be concealed income.

anchor.surface_text: When both these explanations were rejected, as they have been it was clearly upon to the Income-tax Officer to hold that the income must be concealed income.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explanations rejected by Tribunal; credits appear in assessee's firm books; facts warrant inference of undisclosed income.

holdings.text: The conclusion to which the Appellate Tribunal came appears to us to be amply warranted by the facts of the case. There is no ground for interfering with that finding.

anchor.surface_text: The conclusion to which the Appellate Tribunal came appears to us to be amply warranted by the facts of the case. There is no ground for interfering with that finding, and these appeals are accordingly dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal's rejection of explanations and treatment as undisclosed income supported by evidence on benami, gifts, accounts, registration, lack of payments/remuneration.

holdings.text: Seeing that in this case the appellant had moved the High Court and a decision has been pronounced adverse to him and this has become final, obviously it would not be open to him to question the correctness of the decision of the Tribunal on grounds which might have been taken in an appeal against the judgment of the High Court.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Finality of High Court's dismissal of s.66(2) reference application precludes raising same or available grounds in direct Art.136 appeal against Tribunal.

holdings.text: All the points urged before us were taken in the reference under section 66(2) of the Indian Income-tax Act. It would therefore follow that these grounds are not open to the appellant.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Points already adjudicated in dismissed High Court reference not re-agitable in this appeal.

The DOCTRINE_RES_JUDICATA (c7) provides the legal foundation for holding h4, which states that after a final adverse High Court decision, it is not open to the appellant to raise those issues in the Article 136 appeal.
The DOCTRINE_RES_JUDICATA (c7) directly grounds holding h5, which explicitly notes that points taken in the section 66(2) reference are not open in the appeal, matching the doctrine's description.
The doctrine (c7) addresses the issue (i2) of whether a direct Article 136 appeal lies against the Tribunal decision by barring grounds already taken or available in prior reference proceedings.
The fact of the Appellate Tribunal's judgment (f16) triggers issue i2 regarding whether a direct Article 136 appeal lies against that Tribunal decision.
